Hi @Fokko ,
 is this issue solution already merged? if not, i can work on it.

I am using Iceberg version 1.2.0 and I have encountered the same issue and managed to solve it by using the approach suggested by @chajath - I have used the following SDK packages:

- `software.amazon.awssdk:core:2.20.18`
- `software.amazon.awssdk:glue:2.20.18`
- `software.amazon.awssdk:s3:2.20.18`
- `software.amazon.awssdk:sts:2.20.18`
- `software.amazon.awssdk:utils:2.20.18`
- `software.amazon.awssdk:url-connection-client:2.20.18`

I don't think `gc.enabled` has anything to do with old metadata files. Those are known to be owned by the table so it is always okay to delete them. `gc.enabled` was a work-around for situations where we did not know whether data files were owned (e.g. snapshots).

> I never considered sharing metadata files.

Iceberg makes a lot of decisions based on the core assumption that the known state of a table consists of the current metadata file and its references. That's the basis for snapshot expiration, for example. Once a snapshot is no longer referenced by table metadata it can be cleaned up. We introduced the option to be able to skip data file cleanup, but even that is a hack and we should be modelling location ownership.

Sharing metadata files violates the spec because each version of metadata replaces the last. I don't think that we need to consider how reusing or sharing would impact operations. I definitely sympathize with needing to support Nessie, but we were clear about the trade-off from the early days.
I'm +1 for removing this property entirely. It is only used for testing and we've never had a request for it in production.
Thanks for fixing this, @amogh-jahagirdar!
Overall this looks good to me. Thanks for taking the time to work through all the cases with AQE.

> Hi, just for reference, Pamion has integrated [UPDATE](https://github.com/apache/incubator-paimon/pull/1010) & [DELETE](https://github.com/apache/incubator-paimon/issues/786) for flink-1.17. Also in previous investagtion, IIUC, to implement DELETE & UPDATE for iceberg, we may need to finish #7110 first since Iceberg will use the metadata columns, file_path, file_pos to delete data.

The meta columns are required for UPDATE & DELETE on tables without pk. But for tables with pk, we can UPDATE & DELETE using the pk, which does not rely on https://github.com/apache/iceberg/issues/7110. 
In fact, UPDATE & DELETE in Paimon also only supports tables with pk.

IMHO, we can first support tables with pk. While support for tables without pk can be added later, after https://github.com/apache/iceberg/issues/7110 is finished.
@luoyuxia @clownxc What are your thoughts on this? Thanks!

@Fokko In some of our user use cases, the execution of downstream tasks depends on the existence of upstream task result table partitions, without caring about whether the upstream tasks are completed. This is feasible in hive, but migrating to iceberg doesn't work, but we do not want to change user usage habits.

In iceberg that doesn't happen @ZhendongBai, because it's an atomic system either the partition exists or it doesn't. More so, partitions only exist within metadata in the context of a committed datafiles. An Iceberg table by definition cannot have a partition without files. A particular partition value only exists as a field in the listing of a data file's metadata.

Here is what was happening in my case.

1. We have Defined below properties, so metadata can get cleanup regularly.
          write.metadata.delete-after-commit.enabled
          write.metadata.previous-versions-max
2. If your multiple ingestion process running concurrently , these properties might contradict.
3. i am retaining my metadata for bigger value so this issue will not happen. Below are my settings.
      write.metadata.delete-after-commit.enabled= false
      write.metadata.previous-versions-max=200

Thanks @ajantha-bhat . It will be nice to provide an option to have this (optionally) at the time of writing itself. If the user choose to run it explicitly during commit, it could be run and it can help instead of running minor compaction periodically. Again this should be optional and it is a way of providing the flexibility to write compacted delete files during writes in certain cases.

@rbalamohan Keep in mind that combining all the positional deletes might not always be beneficial. If you do a query `SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = 1`, it will only load the deletes that are relevant to the query.

As per me, the main purpose of having MOR is to have faster writes. Writing a bigger delete file (during the write) might defeat that purpose. Let's see what others think.
That is the reason it has to be made optional (depending on need basis of usecase and user pref)

I ran some tests against an aritificial dataset of really small files that originally lead me to dive into the Async client. I found a couple of interesting results.
(The dataset is based on 30k small parquet files ~40KB each derived from [Amazon Book reviews dataset](https://s3.amazonaws.com/amazon-reviews-pds/readme.html) )

1. The async client consistently runs about 20% faster for compacting this dataset with default configuration
2. The async client is also better at internally handling failures, so I see fewer task reruns, and the execution times are more stable/consistent than the older client.

There is still some work required to run this against a standard datasets for validation, and potentially some tuning on the HTTP client choice/configurations. But at this point, it seems to overall take fewer system resources, and shows no downsides.
